command: echo -n K1 > /dev/udp/target.example/32100; sleep 1; echo -n K2 > /dev/udp/target.example/32101; sleep 1; echo -n K3 > /dev/udp/target.example/32102; ssh -p 4422 user@target.example
explanation: Uses Bash's /dev/udp pseudo-device to send three small UDP payload knocks (K1, K2, K3) to specific ports, signaling the remote host to open SSH on 4422, then connects. Detection: look for unusual use of /dev/udp in shell histories; packet inspection for small, ordered UDP payloads to uncommon ports; correlate with subsequent SSH connections from the same source IP.
rationale_steps: Issue three distinct UDP knocks using Bash's /dev/udp to minimize tool footprint.
Remote knock service recognizes the payload sequence and opens SSH.
Initiate SSH once the port is exposed.
Detect by auditing shell history for /dev/udp usage and analyzing UDP-to-SSH correlation.
